awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Alexander Smith is " The Statistics of Selmer Groups in Twist Families." The host institution for the fellowship is Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and the sponsoring scientist is Bjorn Poonen.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
My work was supported by NSF grant 2002011 from September 2020 through June 2021. During that year and continuing to today, my long-term project was to understand the distribution of Selmer groups in families. This work is motivated by its elementary applications. Here is an example of a question we might answer: If a positive integer is chosen at random between 1 and 10^100, what is the chance that it can be written in the form x^3 + y^3 for some rational numbers x and y? Our expectation is that this chance should be about 50%, but this is still conjectural.


Selmer groups are objects with a difficult definition that are invaluable to answer questions like this. If we knew the distribution of Selmer groups in the right family, we could answer the above question directly.


During my period of postdoctoral support by the NSF, I collaborated with Adam Morgan on the paper "The Cassels-Tate pairing for finite Galois modules". With an eye to future statistical work, this paper fleshed out the theory for manipulating Selmer groups, with the titular Cassels-Tate pairing being a key indirect method for controlling these groups.


In addition, I began a second major project. With Raymond van Bommel, Edgar Costa, Wanlin Li, and Bjorn Poonen, I wrote the paper "Abelian varieties of prescribed order over finite fields". Given a prime p and a set of polynomial equations, e.g. x^2 + y^2 = z^2 and x^3 + y^3 = w^3, we might ask how many choices of the unknowns  x, y, z, w mod p there are such that all these equations hold mod p. 


Our intuition is that, if there are more unknowns, there will be more solutions; and if there are more equations, there will be fewer solutions. This is encapsulated in a certain invariant of the sequence of polynomial equations known as the dimension.


In the above paper, we studied simple abelian varieties, which are a special family of objects cut out by polynomial equations. For such objects, there is a well-known result of Weil controlling how many mod p points the object can have in terms of the dimension. We showed that one could not do much better than Weil's bound by constructing abelian varieties with very large and very small point counts given their dimensions.


The objects we were considering, abelian varieties over finite fields, are ones with cryptographical uses. One could hope that the techniques used in our work could give new insight to such objects.
